title: Responding to the Call of Jesus Christ
subject: Theology

document.title: Doctrinal Elements of a Curriculum Framework for the Development of Catechetical Materials for Young People of High School Age

E6C1B016CF914A5C928EEF8FEBE69353.description:
God gives the grace needed to live out our
commitments.

40A0F1B98DEC43E7B26B8F8658956FBB.description:
Committed celibacy for the sake of Jesus Christ
and his Kingdom brings consolation that cannot
be appreciated by one who has not lived it. Living
a life of committed celibacy or chastity gives one a
sense of the gifts of the eternal life to come.

68991C4CEEE4410FB05FD714D5588F21.description:
The heart of celibacy is a truly loving relationship
with the Lord, expressed in a self-gift to others in
his name.

A6C577660867491AAEE904C05791A6DF.description:
Sexual intimacy with another is not essential for
personal fulfillment and happiness.

19086CA123024635B7511FD39D8536E6.description:
Most men who become priests, monks, or brothers
and most women who become nuns, sisters, and
consecrated virgins generally live happy and
fulfilling lives.

ACDCEA36F4E142B3B6F37D01CCD1A7A8.description:
Some who promise lifelong celibacy and chastity
may experience loneliness, as do some married
people.

D49A9616F6BE4B538175A4F66F5C1915.description:
Don’t men and women who promise celibacy or lifelong
chastity live lonely, unhappy lives?

CE3E97B832894C5E9288D151A81CF05D.description:
God does give the grace needed to live out
our commitments.

7ADABFE6698E498FB72B9712BFDD8062.description:
Married love involves not just feelings but also
a commitment of reason and will; married love
cannot deepen unless it faces and overcomes hard
times and adversity.

02513AEB1F6D40D0941CFFE78363AAE0.description:
Jesus Christ has taught us to recognize that the love
between spouses is an image of the unending aspect
of God’s love for us; he has promised to love us, and
he does not break his promises. Neither should we
break promises of marriage.

3D63C3125BAA4EA3BBE3B31AEA4D0090.description:
We know through Revelation that from the
creation of the world and the creation of human
beings, God’s plan included marriage. Jesus Christ
raised marriage to the level of a sacrament and
taught that, properly understood, it involves
lifelong commitment.

35B1F57E071B43448A2C3A90EDA1B509.description:
Failed marriages might be a regular part of life, but
they happen because of our fallen human nature.
God teaches us to see and understand marriage as
something which lasts for life.

4F572A6C436148ECBD3EF91FFDA0A4E6.description:
Just as people fall in love, they also fall out of love. Isn’t
a failed marriage just a regular part of life?

88E6A8438DD54F8394906D08AC912E2D.description:
In the Beatitudes, Jesus Christ teaches us attitudes
essential for true happiness.

BA93576D9A7147EE98885CA396BC12B2.description:
The ultimate goal in life should be holiness; this is
where true success lies.

BEEA6846C75C4C389760D5294F8B766A.description:
Personal satisfaction in life finds a firm foundation
in our relationship with the Lord and secondly in
our relationships with other people.

5A850D9B9E4E485898E5F49F38BB7F29.description:
To some, the measure of success may be money and
physical comforts, but that is not what Jesus Christ
either taught or lived.

1CDC794C79F64423B6E791C816CDDC50.description:
Isn’t the real measure of success in life the degree of
one’s financial security and material comfort?

AB5D1614B7FB43FAAFD465D94C422A48.description:
However, a refusal to answer God’s call may result
in a more difficult road to eternal life, or it may
even jeopardize one’s salvation.

0F840DF587F5459CAA7E70CFDB5DD819.description:
Often the key to happiness is using one’s gifts
fully for God by using them to serve others in
Christian love.

DB8164077D134DF88779035D9BC2D44C.description:
No. The foundational call from God is not to a
particular vocation, job, career, or way of life but to
universal holiness and communion with him. This
is the basis of all happiness.

E03B0FB2BF5B483A883745A43A4F3AAB.description:
Isn’t having the right vocation, job, or career essential
for a person’s happiness?

44B0EE049CA94A8F8382A462D3CE32DF.description:
The Virgin Mary, model of consecration and
discipleship (CCC, nos. 967, 2030).

7E8E8D7FDEED4DE4918FC2D715909888.description: Eschatological dimension of the consecrated life.

4E4F808DB1EA4FE8874EAA35EA065C70.description: Witnesses to Christ in the world.

51D62D39C52C4437B5614BB5FFB06860.description: The Paschal dimension of the consecrated life.

E4A6D520F7D34CEEA5525B324E168316.description: Consecrated like Christ for the Kingdom of God.

A4394DBDC1774F598AB08035F21A99A7.description:
The evangelical counsels: poverty, chastity, and
obedience (CCC, nos. 915-916).

A441F79F17754737BB297EEA95DB6943.description:
New expressions of consecrated life (CCC, nos.
931-933).

4C04FEAA001F405AB6B007555847132D.description:
The order of virgins; hermits and widows (CCC,
nos. 920-924).

84009737E29F40B3AE4BAA2B0AAA5437.description:
The work of the Spirit in the various forms of
consecrated life (CCC, nos. 914-933).

C861A7709E14485988D6292379BE86A0.description:
Purpose of seal or character (CCC, nos.
1581-1584).

C9CA45C56F854200A44AD5C963401DAD.description:
The one ordained is marked with a permanent seal
or character.

48F3A667C48444F9928C24A7E797E823.description:
A deacon is clothed in the vestments of a
deacon (stole and dalmatic) and is presented
with the Book of the Gospels, which he will
proclaim.

CD08E857949045DBB52F71B5BA81EB1B.description:
A priest is clothed in the vestments of a priest
(stole and chasuble) and then is presented with
the bread and wine that will be consecrated.

6C75B1273C3B47BAB72081894EE65C82.description:
A bishop is presented with a ring, a crozier, and
a miter.

5B9DBA8884714B8AA1A164BEF89913AA.description: Unique elements at the ordination of each.

1FF25CBB12604176B61C68B8026D5867.description:
At the ordination of a bishop, chrism is poured
on his head.

E0CA76059B8540719228758738756E9D.description:
At the ordination of a priest, his hands are
anointed with chrism.

64204AEE61A84F77BDDB5981131550AF.description:
Chrism is used in the ordination of a priest and of a
bishop (CCC, no. 1574).

F19F19B555664D408BED5CDEEDA8D7F8.description:
Essential element of each order is the laying on of
hands by the bishop and the consecratory prayer
(CCC, no. 1573).

3790BD542D1A41BAAD5ADD70F76D4536.description:
Permanent deacons participate in a number of years
of part-time preparation.

C5A7399CFCB14DF6B1AAE00B01C82B2F.description:
A transitional deacon is prepared as part of his
training for priesthood (CCC, nos. 1569-1571).

20789E145FFB4157A2090BE0FD91FFF0.description:
Priests in religious institutes must also
embrace vows.

0450979430AC43BDA7240B66E66FB66B.description:
Understanding and embracing the promises
he makes.

015B837A81E9435384C4D3AC3445E545.description:
Human, intellectual, spiritual, and pastoral
development.

0466E6B4D92040A1AC8C458525AC49B7.description:
A priest is prepared through years of formation in
a seminary.

B25A9E03DDB044B8A56608FD6D2EA2E3.description: Prayer and discernment by the candidate.

94F19CD6063D42029F49027D61745E51.description:
As a child, there is the example of parish
priests and the encouragement from family and
community.

6B6910A569A44A91BFB0ABF2C7519477.description:
A bishop is prepared through ministry as a priest
and through a life of prayer and sacrifice.

2F68DBA30DF54FC9B83032A8AD9402D3.description:
There is no historical basis for women serving
as deacons in the diaconate as we now know
and understand it.

5A4F2BF631EB419B9C942D774CAA404A.description:
Bishop or priest serves as an icon of Christ:
head of his Body, bridegroom of the Church.

C9941221D4764601A09672982B6CD9BF.description:
It is the matter of what Christ has
established, and the sacramental reality
and symbolism of the priestly office.

01C4959BB1F7447CB69EE757A8CD5F09.description:
It is not a question of the ability to carry
out the functions of the ministry.

DF5BC3899B6446C79C0C7152F377D037.description:
“The Church has no authority whatsoever to
confer priestly ordination on women” (OS,
no. 4).

BC2BDE340F5D4BB7A7060536A11C4DF5.description:
Holy Orders is a sacrament reserved to men (CCC,
no. 1577).

F588583E0E1943989D0FD0A97E5E23FA.description:
Permanent: some men (including married
men) are ordained deacons for life.

6C40E4A581704556B0BBCC0510E43F01.description:
Transitional: before being ordained a
priest, a man is first ordained a deacon and
serves in that role generally for six months
to a year.

8A5758B536944F61907AF4893CB63E11.description:
In the Eastern Churches the deacon is not the
ordinary minister of Baptism and also cannot
solemnize or witness a marriage.

D1BE92EDB3C14899BA53B256306CC422.description:
Assists at and blesses marriages
(CCC, no. 1630).

4B9E934552084A97A9BDE157DD2DB77B.description:
Assists in celebration of the divine mysteries
(CCC, no. 1570).

09DD90790E344E2CAFBE1A4644356CDE.description:
Special focus of deacon is ministry of
charitable service.

E31665CB7ABD4CC680A9A68CDAB3FF7B.description:
Ordained by bishop to be of service to him and
his priests.

21C7F4103A104D569571BBDF83E3D56B.description:
In Sacrament of Marriage in the Latin
Church, the priest receives the consent
of the spouses in name of the Church and
gives blessing of the Church (CCC, no.
1630).

CAF7FCB69FB74C4DB0194516B1461BFF.description:
Sacraments of Baptism (and Chrismation
in the Eastern Churches), Eucharist,
Penance, Anointing of the Sick, and
Confirmation in certain circumstances.

6F426F091C334BE2842C36D63BDDD025.description:
Generally serves in a parish; only a priest can
serve as a pastor of a parish.

9263052F849B4E4D889051047C371141.description:
Special focus of priest is ministry of the Word
and of the sacraments.

E4344C5E71154FDDBF3026F67394A083.description: Ordained by bishop as co-worker with bishop.

469E4C5E7FC34F2992CCCBF2C7CC8441.description:
Priest acts in the person of Christ: in persona
Christi capitis.

F9A77F9F9960475EB50A4451D18AE480.description:
Archbishops and cardinals (or patriarch or
major archbishop in some Eastern Churches).

6470FFE8A9D64E418D43FD4CDF57CE50.description: Chosen by the pope from among priests.

E251B2C418EB42B3A5ECFE56A0077394.description: Ordination is reserved to bishops alone.

F0992CB189B04B1892AFB30A5FE0E43D.description:
Confirmation generally conferred by
bishops in the Latin Church.

372DE7CC3126467FB7D682D29533F2C7.description:
Bishop is understood as “married” to diocese;
this is partly why he wears a ring.

1C6CABC3F33A479A85F2CCA94F009FC2.description:
The bishop is the shepherd and high priest
of a diocese, responsible for teaching and
sanctifying his flock and proclaiming the truth
to all; he wears a miter and carries a crozier to
symbolize this.

A4F54003FFC84DCEBFB907C3EFF4A066.description:
A member of the college of bishops in
communion with pope.

2B1685FCA21D47A499740EF0D4C37A40.description:
Bishop (office of sanctifying, teaching, and
governing) (CCC, nos. 1555-1561).

12E25D6CA856439C9CFFDE8A410D6AE4.description: The three degrees of Holy Orders.

37B4F8CA65FE492680E290BC04CE45DC.description:
Original deacons were ordained to serve material
needs of community (Acts 6:1-7).

9D9760300E4341E086BDF28E2F2D32D0.description:
As the Church grew, Apostles and successors
ordained priests as their co-workers.

FDA0999BC7964C468C05E270A7626FEA.description:
Apostles as the pastors and leaders of the early
Church, the first bishops.

741B4126F2D04F7A9E4CCDFCC24A0F4B.description:
Historical development of the three orders of
the sacrament.

9E18473A44CB446F86E23ABD58676281.description:
Instituted by Christ at the Last Supper as a sign of
the Lord’s abiding presence and priestly action in the
Church (CCC, no. 1564).

2E0105EF95914B7BB078A7819D3D62A5.description:
If one or both were forced into the
marriage.

8C1318EC3F9545C19C25671E7A6A7342.description:
If one or both of the spouses lacked the
psychological capacity to assume the
essential obligations of marriage.

4CA784517B2344CFBE54AB95195636B9.description: Other reasons for declaration of nullity.

3EB8FBE2448F4CF19E9EEB74DF5C9530.description:
A declaration of nullity of marriage can be
issued if it is proven that there was a defect of
consent, a defect of form, or the existence of
an impediment (CCC, nos. 1625-1632).

D6C9F04DA7544C259FCD5864E42CCB69.description:
Determining the validity of previous marriage of
divorced Catholics.

94B0F191794B482094C8E4C3A746A95C.description:
Ineligible to serve as a sponsor for Baptism
or Confirmation.

500490828772465A996935B97AE23FEB.description:
They are not separated from the Church
and are obligated to attend Sunday Mass
but are barred from the reception of
sacraments except in danger of death.

A4AAFB1AE1B7443E956CA600DF387CFF.description:
Catholic parties in a civil marriage are
living in an objective state of sin; they are
also a source of scandal to others.

925D966CAA8C43A8886BA4909B118FFE.description:
Consequences for divorced Catholics who
attempt marriage without a declaration of
nullity (CCC, no. 1665).

4A0A100E883047E6888BC2028A6EE8DD.description:
Sacraments for divorced but not remarried
Catholics.

8A83E448ED31465DBD184F13BD5340E8.description:
Civil divorce does not end a valid sacramental
marriage.

6938FAF1125A41F39372D1188304F07D.description:
When and why a civil divorce may be permitted
(CCC, no. 1649).

DEDAE0C98EBC420F997570B06CC46C44.description:
Christ teaches that a marriage lasts as long as both
parties are still alive (CCC, no. 1650).

A66BF8841A354A9BBC09BD902DA82B27.description: The question of divorce and/or remarriage.

EE31585B6C2C430BA112AF0244D77352.description: Natural authority of parents is challenged.

8AA2AE10A117400E98239AE14C372C7B.description:
Lack of willingness to accept children as a gift
from God.

3C9AEE1AEE874157B7931F98877B8332.description: Loss of respect for the dignity of all human beings.

2A3249EFA340463A9979A7A388C64277.description:
Financial burdens; need for both parents to work
outside the home.

C6D07DBA572441C8875AD9626146187F.description: Blended families; loss of the extended family ties.

CEEDA4B36D314A40A2A0315AA3105334.description:
Impact of images in media, and challenges to
traditional marriage in law.

2D77C70912C44FF3B8F97E60A57FEB61.description:
Social challenges: acceptance of divorce and
46
Doctrinal Elements of a Curriculum Framework for the
Development of Catechetical Materials for Young People of High School Age
remarriage; popular cultural values are pushing aside
traditional values; cohabitation before marriage;
weakening of the bond between husband and wife.

88F534028D444361A970B1DBC81F5254.description:
Challenges to marriage and family life (CCC, nos.
1649-1651).

B7EC61DF75A14B0CBF06C8842EA8F345.description:
Witness of faithful couples strengthens church
community and the fabric of society (CCC, nos.
1655-1658).

56668F9B89B9448495C1FD33ED4850FE.description:
When blessed with children, parents are helped
to raise them in faith and love (CCC, nos. 1652-
1654).

556F5D0292A342B0AD884EB18221332E.description:
Couples are given the grace which strengthens
them to attain eternal life (CCC, nos. 1617, 1639,
1641).

C1F42254F2AE478A87D7BBC6B5DCCE55.description:
Also the grace to strengthen the permanent nature
of their union and to appreciate the joy their union
can bring (CCC, no. 1615).

1CBCB013902D4D34AF8415BA0725DDD7.description:
Married couples are given the grace to love
unselfishly.

0A232B598B2B48A1A71A9C9F8455732D.description:
Teach practical skills to help couples live what
they promise.

00E7338D56F548A5935E8D3C8BB54480.description:
Help engaged persons grow in knowledge of
self, their future spouse, and their relationship.

80FF75743CEC41529B386AAC7C35A1DD.description:
Dioceses require period of preparation that
varies by diocese.

0B7B0977BFD642809F1641870110934C.description:
Church’s responsibility to prepare couples
for marriage.

AD39732CB7E444EB872468A7269A6833.description:
Develop skills for living a lifelong
commitment.

31EF166879EC44B7A76C33342216B313.description:
Marriage reflects Christ’s relationship to the
Church (Eph 5:21-33; CCC, no. 1642).

0E8EF0E2394344AFA3754C5239F84B4F.description: Healthy personal and dating habits as a highschool-aged person.

047978E245244E7FBC5BB24127DFEE72.description:
Expressions of healthy sexual relations
in marriage.

45AE15629CB249C69B6944157A5B0CE4.description:
Marriage involves a total self-giving of
the spouses; requires a sense of discipline,
generosity, and an understanding of true love.

2E2F145D66BB445CA0161312A71FA8D5.description:
God decreed that sexual intimacy be reserved
for marriage.

C067351FB30D4133B46120DCEBD14396.description:
God made man and woman with a natural
complementarity (see Genesis: both
creation accounts).

33228C9A33D242919CE4EF0AB7277139.description:
Sexuality part of our being; we relate through
personhood that includes sexuality.

7CFEC99DDE4D43B3889D4CD6CA0BA8CC.description:
Need for healthy self-understanding
including sexuality.

16AC46108DED43CBB7E3D35BFE70E908.description:
Remote preparation begins as children, through
example of parents, relatives, and other members of
the community.

3BE7C1CA04074758A5B7E76CD8165E1A.description:
Preparation for receiving the sacrament (CCC, no.
1622; FC, no. 66).

43225913E3F64A19B9A61FC665616FF4.description:
Conditions for this permission to marry nonCatholic: Catholic party promises to maintain
the practice of his or her faith and to raise any
children they have in the Catholic faith.

4B5CA5765E31442CB3BAFBC18BEF5DB1.description:
Permission can be given to marry those who
are not Catholic.

5D84C887C65B4C5BB38A8A6DA58B6904.description:
A Catholic is encouraged to marry another
Catholic (CCC, nos. 1633-1637).

CB457F3AFD7044EB95E85655FD4371FD.description:
In Latin Church, the Nuptial Mass—or just the
Liturgy of the Word (see Directory for the Application
of Principles and Norms on Ecumenism, no. 159).

05A6C6D326AE4328948690B6D832C342.description:
In the Eastern Churches, the bishop or priest
confers the Sacrament of Matrimony.

AB267A7AF3CB493D924BD57D81F0A986.description: The essential three promises of the spouses.

9F96F5A2A93A4E2DB5914430C5672633.description:
Role of free consent, and witness of bishop,
priest, deacon.

6C9553E6C65A4F7584F60C477CC25C51.description:
In the Latin Church the spouses are ministers
of the sacrament.

73588C9D4D9E40D7B6D038DF662466FE.description: For Roman Catholics—setting for a valid marriage.

506BA0579EC64D6DB984FE715FF410A7.description:
Marriage: a public act that requires a liturgical
celebration (CCC, nos. 1621-1623).

FC6E9C97B9404711818B784AE6023FBF.description:
Cohabitation and homosexual union as a
devaluation of the true meaning of marriage
(CCC, nos. 2353-2359).

2C27399E76C049F0B7364F16E61A64F3.description:
Scourge of abortion, recourse to sterilization,
contraceptive mentality (CCC, nos. 2270-
2274, 2370, 2399).

E112D9C76FC04BDB9293B5D6AC6631C2.description:
Exaggeration of the independence of the
spouses to the loss of mutual dependence and
becoming two in one flesh (FC, no. 6; CCC,
nos. 1606-1608).

FE7C08BEF466443AB5D3AAF70737D266.description:
Problems encountered in marriage and family life
(CCC, nos. 2331-2359).

DA675DC2149241E59BAEB83A2C4695A0.description:
Mutual self-giving within marriage and family
serves as basis for responsible activity in society
and in the Church.

335D9E971EE444839564233F195786D5.description:
Education of children and extended family
support (CCC, nos. 1603-1605).

238213E753FA4CA9B0C3A636AFBBB279.description:
Promotes the dignity of both men and women
(CCC, nos. 1646-1651).

1E237C403424409689C5BFB6DD4CB563.description:
Greater awareness of personal freedom and
interpersonal relationships.

7B6A593A22CA485D99F02210B546C0AA.description:
Encouraging signs of Christ’s saving work in
marriage and the family.

2E145731B50A42C18D244A88C89B1DFC.description:
Christian marriage is a lifelong commitment between
a baptized man and a baptized woman as husband and
wife, designed to reflect the unending love that God has
for his people, individually and collectively; a covenant
of love (CCC, no. 1625).

AA3708CCB76140E481959625AC3DDCC6.description:
The love of husbands and wives reflecting the
love of Christ for the Church (Eph 5; CCC,
no. 1616).

24F9E06929284852A8CFEBD431435432.description:
Two shall become as one flesh; and the
question on divorce (Mt 19; CCC, no. 1614).

8BDE12AE88834E0BB0C73A27028942FC.description:
Jesus’ first public sign or miracle took place at a
marriage (Jn 2:1-11; CCC, no. 1613).

5CF096CEB8FB454EB65F781D0AE04819.description:
Teaching on marriage in the New Testament
(CCC, no. 1615).

0BE3A203F05C43D395325BF79CAB38A7.description:
God is author of marriage, which Jesus raised to a
sacrament; it is not a purely human institution (CCC,
nos. 1603, 1601).

C0B6453752EA41A097A89452FBEC4339.description:
Holy Orders as a sacrament given to foster the
good of the spiritual family, the Church (CCC,
nos. 1536-1600).

4C5654CAABAB4E73AEB7283AF2914D64.description:
Marriage as a sacrament given to foster the good of
the human family, society, and the Church (CCC,
nos. 1601-1666).

4C9DE86777AC4E82B795DF5EE2B88157.description:
Sacraments at the service of Communion (CCC, nos.
1533-1535).

2277D86EA42E45CD86BA648A5552107C.description:
Service to our brothers and sisters in the Church
and world.

577A5232EBEB42F68A830EF6CCE48525.description: An unselfish gift of self to God and others.

9D82035B9C0A4E72B4DCBC8BB760F435.description:
Teaching and example of Jesus—his commandment of
love (CCC, no. 1823).

428A48A2A41445C38181BE8ABD856DBB.description:
There are many levels and types of
relationship.

42BDC6431EA24ACE8E22C235B5F57E71.description:
Human beings exist in relationship with
others; give of oneself in order to find oneself

6B1F4BC1D9EC404FB9C41E211287E62A.description:
No vocation is lived in isolation (CCC, nos. 543,
804, 831, 1886, 1878-1885).

88196256B65C408983AD4E2DB407F902.description:
Lay ecclesial movements and ministries (CCC,
nos. 901-913).

BC76F68EDF6A4BAA9487D863CF044265.description:
Ordained bishop, priest, or deacon (CCC,
nos. 1578, 1593).

1574821620C8494890A774FA56B68B41.description:
Traditionally recognized states of life (CCC, nos.
2004, 2230).

90B9A326D14846D591E914623A789AA4.description: Divine Providence in the events of one’s life.

D638A6717E314CA79EF96DDEB667E70C.description:
Definition/description of discernment—role of
Church and individual.
